p.s: In the given scene the topic of their forbidden love is in the focus.
How they reflect on their love against the odds becomes clear by taking a close look at the stylistic devices.
The extract begins with the personification: My ears have not yet drunk a hundred words of that tongue's utterance, yet I know the sound(ll. 58f).
Juliet immediately recognizes Romeo's voice even though they have only seen each other once at the masquerade where they fell in love.
Thus, Juliet seems to already know him very well which expresses her love at first for him and their connection.

As a reaction to Juliet's concern about him putting himself at risk by entering Capulet property and climbing over the wall he makes use of the metaphor With love's light wings did I o'er-perch these walls (l. 66).
Therefore, his love for Juliet gives him the ability and the bravery to put himself at risk for her and climb over the wall.

Love's light wings also embodysembodies the ease that he climbed the wall with and the positive feeling the love created in him since wings are associated to angels and birds which resemble freedom and the peace of heaven.
That Romeo is not scared of the kinsmen and his own death is enhanced with the similyesimile in (ll. 71f) Alack, there lies more peril in thine eye than twenty of their swords: look thou but sweet.
Romeo does not see the danger in the kinsmen but in the possibility that Juliet could not love him back.
He knows that their love is against the odds and is aware of the fact that the Capulets would kill him in the case taht they geas him.
Nevertheless, he is not scared of his death and their weapons but only desires that Juliet reciprocates his feelings.
As a result, his love appears to be immense and honest as he made it all the dangerous way at night to her house.
Just to confess his love he put his life at risk.

Additionally, he underlines again that he would rather want to die if Juliet does not love him by contrasting life and death as well as hate and love in (ll. 77f) he explains My life were better ended by their hate, than death prorouged, wanting of thy love.
Here he puts the family's hatred into focus again.
The dramatic effect is emphasized by the contrast of life and death where it becomes clear that Romeo would rather die loving her than live and not having her.
This is of great importance to the further plot of the drama as Romeo commits suicide because he thinks that Juliet is dead.

But also the contrast of hate and love is essential to the play as it illustrates that their family's grudge complicates their love and that Romeo and Juliet still love each other even though they were raised to hate each other.
The extent of Romeo's love is underlined in (ll. 83f) with the metaphor As that vast shore wash'd with the farthest sea, I would adventure for sure merchandise.
So even if their love would be even more complicated and if she would be even further away, he would still do anything to find her.
Moreover, he compares her to a merchandise which implicates of what high value she is to him.
Even though Juliet is very touched by his words she still seems to have concerns about the strenghtstrength and the pace of their love and wants a clear answer and promise from Romeo.

Thus, she questions his love and her behaviour just to be sure in (l. 90) Dost thou love me?, in (l. 95)Or if thou think'st I am too quickly won and in (l. 99) And therefore thou mayst think my behaviour light.
Juliet seems to be sure about herself loving Romeo but still not certain how Romeo percievesperceives her and is longing for his validation.
In order to convince Juliet that he is serious, Romeo swears by the moon.

The multiple repetitions of the word swear (ll. 107,109,112,113,114) illustrate how important it is to the two lovers to ensure their love so they can count on the other's reliability and trust since they later decide to get married.
Juliet does not want Romeo to swear by the moon as he changes constantly but asks him to swear by his gracious self (l. 114) in order to trust him.
All in all, it gets clear that Romeo and Juliet are both very certain about their love for the other but still needed the validation that the feelings are on both sides.
They are aware of the dangers and difficulties about their love but both conclude that their lvoe is stronger than the family's hatred.
